questions.text: A neuron is receiving 400 inputs from 150 sensory neurons. This is an example of? How would you categorize a situation where a single neuron receives inputs from 150 sensory neurons, totaling to 400 inputs? ( INICET Nov 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Convergence

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Convergence is when multiple neurons synapse onto a single neuron, integrating inputs from various sources. In the scenario described, where one neuron receives inputs from 150 sensory neurons, convergence is the appropriate term.

questions.text: A patient had enlarging nodules present on his scalp. He was taking prednisolone, mycophenolate mofetil, and tacrolimus. His clinical lesion and the histopathological lesion are shown alongside. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Malakoplakia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Malakoplakia is a rare granulomatous condition marked by Michaelis-Guttmann bodies and is often seen in immunosuppressed patients. It can affect organs beyond the urinary bladder, including the skin.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient presented to the outpatient department with migratory arthritis and examination revealed a pan-systolic murmur. An echocardiography was performed which was suggestive of mitral regurgitation. A biopsy specimen was obtained and the image is provided below. What is the most likely lesion shown in the histopathology slide? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Aschoff’s bodies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aschoff bodies, which consist of lymphocytes, plasma cells, and characteristic Anitschkow cells, are the hallmark histological feature of acute rheumatic fever, a condition that can lead to significant cardiac involvement, including mitral regurgitation.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with a cough with yellowish sputum. Auscultation revealed bronchial breath sounds. He is hemodynamically stable and not confused. On examination, his respiratory rate is 20/min and blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. Lab reports show urea levels of 44 mg/dL. What is the next best step in the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: Give antibiotics and send the patient home

options.label: B
options.text: Admit to ICU without mechanical ventilation

options.label: C
options.text: Admit to ICU with invasive mechanical ventilation

options.label: D
options.text: Consider admission in a non-ICU setting

questions.correct_answer: D. Consider admission in a non-ICU setting
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Consider admission in a non-ICU setting

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For patients with pneumonia, the CURB-65 score is a useful tool for determining the appropriate level of care. A score of 2 typically indicates the need for inpatient treatment in a non-ICU setting.

questions.text: Identify the given image: ( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Gaucher’s disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The given image shows crumpled tissue paper appearance of macrophage cells (see images below) which is a characteristic feature of Gaucher’s disease. This disease is a type of sphingolipidoses and occurs due to deficiency of enzyme β-glucosyl ceramidase.

questions.text: As per the latest MTP act, termination of failed contraception is allowed till which weeks of contraception? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 20 weeks

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The MTP Act permits termination of pregnancy due to failed contraception up to 20 weeks.

questions.text: Consider the following Statements? ( INICET Nov 2023) Statement 1- Contemplation – A person who smokes is thinking of quitting smoking Statement 2- Precontemplation – A person is considering starting morning walks and its benefits to the health Statement 3- Maintenance phase/determination phase – A person quit smoking one year back and has not smoked since then Statement 4- Action phase – A person with obesity says he cant’s do anything as it runs deep in his family
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Statement 1 and 3 are correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Behavior change – 6 stages –
  • ➤ Precontemplation → Contemplation → Preparation/ Determination → Action/will power → Maintenance → Termination

questions.text: A patient presents to you with left-sided flank pain. A CT scan was done which is shown below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the condition? (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: B
options.text: Cyst contents can produce anaphylactic reaction

options.label: C
options.text: A segmented dog tapeworm is the causative agent

options.label: D
options.text: FNAC or biopsy to be done before nephrectomy

questions.correct_answer: D. FNAC or biopsy to be done before nephrectomy
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) FNAC or biopsy to be done before nephrectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Hydatid disease, caused by Echinococcus granulosus, is characterized by cyst formation in organs such as the liver, lungs, and kidneys. FNAC or biopsy should not be done in cases of suspected hydatid cysts due to the risk of anaphylaxis and dissemination of the infection.

questions.text: A person reported to OPD alongside his 32-year-old brother working in a factory. The brother was recently subjected to a test – Coproporphyrin in urine. The physician should suspect: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Coproporphyrin in urine is an important screening test for lead poisoning, indicating exposure to lead, and should be followed by diagnostic tests to assess absorption.

questions.text: Extra row of eyelashes behind the grey line is called as? ( NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Distichiasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Distichiasis is the condition where an extra row of eyelashes grows behind the normal lash line, often leading to corneal irritation and requiring treatment such as cryotherapy or electrolysis to prevent complications.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presented with the following lesion. The abnormality seen following the lesion is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Craniopharyngiomas commonly cause bitemporal hemianopia due to compression of the optic chiasm, resulting in peripheral vision loss on both sides.

questions.text: Correct about trial of labor in a previous LSCS (Lower Segment Cesarean Section) is? (FMGE JULY 2024)

options.label: B
options.text: Emergency cesarean facility should be there

questions.correct_answer: B. Emergency cesarean facility should be there
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Emergency cesarean facility should be there

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The correct answer is emergency cesarean facility should be there . When considering a trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC), it is crucial to ensure that the facility is equipped to handle an emergency cesarean section. This is because the risk of complications, including uterine rupture, can pose significant risks to both the mother and the fetus.
  • • emergency cesarean facility should be there
  • • Emergency cesarean facility : The availability of an emergency cesarean section facility is essential for any patient undergoing TOLAC. This ensures that if complications arise, such as uterine rupture, immediate surgical intervention can be provided to minimize risks.
  • • Emergency cesarean facility
  • • Other Option:
  • • Other Option:
  • • Option A. Risk of uterine rupture is 4-9% : This statement is incorrect for a lower segment cesarean section. The risk of uterine rupture in a TOLAC for a lower segment cesarean section is much lower, around 0.2%. The 4-9% risk applies to upper segment or classical cesarean sections.
  • • Option A. Risk of uterine rupture is 4-9%
  • • Additional Considerations for TOLAC:
  • • Additional Considerations for TOLAC:
  • • Interval between pregnancies : The inter-delivery interval should be more than 18 months to allow adequate healing of the uterine scar. Reason for previous cesarean : Conditions like cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD) or other recurrent indications may reduce the likelihood of a successful TOLAC and increase the risk of complications. Monitoring : Continuous fetal monitoring during labor is recommended to detect any signs of fetal distress early.
  • • Interval between pregnancies : The inter-delivery interval should be more than 18 months to allow adequate healing of the uterine scar.
  • • Interval between pregnancies
  • • Reason for previous cesarean : Conditions like cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD) or other recurrent indications may reduce the likelihood of a successful TOLAC and increase the risk of complications.
  • • Reason for previous cesarean
  • • Monitoring : Continuous fetal monitoring during labor is recommended to detect any signs of fetal distress early.
  • • Monitoring

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When attempting a trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC) , ensure that an emergency cesarean facility is available to handle any complications, particularly the risk of uterine rupture.
  • ➤ trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC)
  • ➤ emergency cesarean facility

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image: ( INICET Nov 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Marbling

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Marbling is a postmortem change characterized by greenish-black streaks on the skin due to the formation of sulfhemoglobin, becoming prominent 24-48 hours after death.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man suffering from persistent fatigue and lymph node enlargement visits the outpatient department. Examination of his peripheral smear reveals the presence of smudge cells. To further establish a diagnosis, what additional investigations will you conduct? ( INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Flow cytometry

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Flow cytometry is the primary diagnostic tool for confirming Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia, particularly in cases where smudge cells are identified on a peripheral smear.

questions.text: Asymmetrical ion differentiation on the cell membrane is due to: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Gibbs Donan reaction explains the asymmetrical ion differentiation on the cell membrane due to the presence of non-diffusible ions and the semi-permeable nature of the membrane.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best test for long-term control of diabetes? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) HbA1C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HbA1C is the best test for evaluating long-term control of diabetes, providing an average of blood glucose levels over the past 2 to 3 months.

questions.text: What event takes place when the retina is exposed to light? ( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.correct_answer: B. Hyperpolarization, decrease in neurotransmitter release
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hyperpolarization, decrease in neurotransmitter release

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Light exposure results in the hyperpolarization of photoreceptor cells in the retina, leading to a decrease in the release of the neurotransmitter glutamate. This process is crucial for converting light signals into electrical signals that can be processed by the brain to form visual images.

questions.text: Identify the marked nerve. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The medial pectoral nerve is the nerve that pierces the pectoralis minor muscle and also provides innervation to the pectoralis major.

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic smoker is diagnosed with peripheral vascular disease. Identify the true statement about intermittent claudication: (NEET PG 2020)

options.label: B
options.text: Most commonly felt in the calf muscles

options.label: C
options.text: Day to day distance is variable

options.label: D
options.text: Relived after getting out of bed

questions.correct_answer: B. Most commonly felt in the calf muscles
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Most commonly felt in the calf muscles

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Intermittent claudication is most commonly felt in the calf muscles due to the high prevalence of peripheral artery disease affecting the arteries that supply the lower limbs. This condition is typically brought on by physical activity and relieved by rest.

questions.text: A patient with crushed limb after amputation developed crepitus. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Gas gangrene

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The patient had a crushed limb that required amputation. After the amputation, the patient developed crepitus, which refers to the presence of gas bubbles in the tissues. The development of crepitus after an injury or amputation suggests a gas-forming bacterial infection, specifically gas gangrene. Gas gangrene is caused by the bacteria Clostridium species, primarily Clostridium perfringens, which can contaminate wounds from soil or other environmental sources. Clostridium perfringens is a gas-forming bacteria that ferments sugars (such as glucose in the body) into acid and gas, leading to tissue necrosis and the formation of gas bubbles (crepitus) in the gangrenous tissue.
  • • The patient had a crushed limb that required amputation.
  • • After the amputation, the patient developed crepitus, which refers to the presence of gas bubbles in the tissues.
  • • The development of crepitus after an injury or amputation suggests a gas-forming bacterial infection, specifically gas gangrene.
  • • Gas gangrene is caused by the bacteria Clostridium species, primarily Clostridium perfringens, which can contaminate wounds from soil or other environmental sources.
  • • Clostridium perfringens is a gas-forming bacteria that ferments sugars (such as glucose in the body) into acid and gas, leading to tissue necrosis and the formation of gas bubbles (crepitus) in the gangrenous tissue.
  • • The presence of crepitus, along with the history of a crushed limb and amputation, strongly suggests gas gangrene as the diagnosis.
  • • Established agents:
  • • Established agents:
  • • C. perfringens C. novyi C. septicum
  • • C. perfringens
  • • C. novyi
  • • C. septicum
  • • Probable agents: C. histolyticum, C. sporogenes, C. fallax, C. bifermentans, C. sordellii, C. aerofoetidum, and C. tertium.
  • • Probable agents:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Cellulitis: This is a bacterial skin infection characterized by redness, swelling, and warmth, but it does not typically involve the formation of gas bubbles.
  • • Option A. Cellulitis:
  • • Option B. Necrotizing fasciitis: This is a severe bacterial infection of the fascia (connective tissue) that can lead to tissue necrosis, but it is not specifically associated with the formation of gas bubbles.
  • • Option B. Necrotizing fasciitis:
  • • Option C. Folliculitis: This is an infection of the hair follicles, which is unlikely to occur after an amputation and does not involve gas formation.
  • • Option C. Folliculitis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gas gangrene is a potentially life-threatening infection caused by gas-forming Clostridium species, primarily Clostridium perfringens. It is characterized by the formation of gas bubbles (crepitus) in the necrotic and gangrenous tissues, typically occurring after traumatic injuries or surgical procedures that allow the contamination of wounds with soil or environmental sources.

questions.text: 'c' wave in JVP is seen in which phase of cardiac cycle? (NEET PG 2018)

options.label: B
options.text: Slow filling at end of diastole

questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Iso-volumetric contraction

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • 'c' waves are produced by bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during the Iso-volumetric contraction of the right ventricle.
  • • The isovolumetric contraction phase is characterized by a closed tricuspid valve and a still-closed pulmonary valve, which causes the pressure in the ventricle to rise rapidly without changing its volume.
  • • Fig : Intra-arterial pressure changes during cardiac cycle. a, c, v= Positive wave x, x 1 , y= Negative waves
  • • Fig
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Slow filling at end of diastole : Incorrect because this phase involves the heart filling with blood, not contracting.
  • • Option B. Slow filling at end of diastole
  • • Option C. End of systole : Incorrect as this phase corresponds to the onset of ventricular relaxation, not contraction.
  • • Option C. End of systole
  • • Option D. Start of diastole : Incorrect because the start of diastole is marked by ventricular relaxation and opening of the atrioventricular valves for ventricular filling, not contraction.
  • • Option D. Start of diastole

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient has microcytic hypochromic anemia and was observed to have delayed wound healing after a minor surgery. He gives history of gum bleeding also. He is most likely to have deficiency of: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vitamin C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) is crucial for collagen synthesis, a vital component of skin and vascular tissues. Deficiency leads to scurvy, which manifests with symptoms like gum bleeding, poor wound healing, and anemia. The anemia is typically normocytic but can be microcytic due to associated blood loss and iron deficiency.
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 548
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 548

questions.text: Identify the condition shown. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Jejunal atresia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "triple bubble" sign is indicative of jejunal atresia, where three dilated segments are visible on the radiograph: the stomach, proximal duodenum, and distal duodenum. This sign is crucial for differentiating jejunal atresia from other types of intestinal obstructions like duodenal atresia or small bowel obstruction.

questions.text: A patient presented in the ER with hypotension. On auscultation, dullness of heart sound and dilated neck veins was diagnosed, along with cardiac tamponade. Which of the following JVP findings is typically associated with cardiac tamponade? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Absent y descent

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In cardiac tamponade, there is an accumulation of fluid in the pericardial sac, which impairs the filling of the heart chambers, particularly during diastole. This results in the characteristic absence of the y descent in the jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform.
  • • The y descent normally represents the rapid filling phase of the right atrium and right ventricle.
  • • In cardiac tamponade, this filling is restricted, leading to a blunted or absent y descent.
  • • Mnemonic "No ThankYou" → No/ Absence of the Y descent in cardiac T amponade.
  • • No/ Absence
  • • Y
  • • T
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Prominent x descent: This is typically seen in conditions with increased atrial relaxation and tricuspid regurgitation, but not in cardiac tamponade.
  • • Option A. Prominent x descent:
  • • Option B. Cannon a wave: This is associated with conditions involving atrioventricular dissociation, such as complete heart block, where atrial contractions occur against a closed tricuspid valve.
  • • Option B. Cannon a wave:
  • • Option D. Absent a wave: The a wave is absent in atrial fibrillation, where there is no coordinated atrial contraction.
  • • Option D. Absent a wave:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cardiac tamponade, the characteristic JVP finding is the absence of the y descent.

questions.text: A patient was given 0.5% bupivacaine for supraclavicular brachial plexus block. In a matter of few seconds the patient suddenly developed hypotension and arrhythmias. Which of the following is the correct 1 st line treatment of this patient? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Intra lipid infusion

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient's symptoms of hypotension and arrhythmias after the administration of 0.5% bupivacaine suggest local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), which can occur if the local anesthetic enters the systemic circulation in significant amounts. Intravenous lipid emulsion (ILE) therapy is considered the first-line treatment for LAST. It works by creating a "lipid sink" that helps to sequester the lipophilic local anesthetic away from target organs, particularly the heart and brain.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Invasive Ventilation: This is provided if the patient is not able to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation on their own. It is supportive care and does not directly counteract the toxicity of the local anesthetic.
  • • Option A. Invasive Ventilation:
  • • Option C. Soda Bicarbonate (Sodium Bicarbonate): This can be used to treat metabolic acidosis, which may occur secondary to hypoxia or cardiac arrest. While it can help in the supportive management of LAST, it is not the first line for the toxicity itself.
  • • Option C. Soda Bicarbonate (Sodium Bicarbonate):
  • • Option D. Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPCR): This is initiated in the case of cardiac arrest. While it's a crucial component of resuscitation, it's not a first-line treatment for the toxicity unless the patient has progressed to cardiac arrest.
  • • Option D. Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPCR):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The first-line treatment for local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST) is intravenous lipid emulsion therapy, which helps to reduce the systemic toxicity of lipophilic local anesthetic agents such as bupivacaine.

questions.text: Edges of a Basal Cell Carcinoma are? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Rolled out beaded

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The correct answer is rolled out beaded.
  • • Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common type of skin cancer, typically occurring in areas with high sun exposure. It often presents initially as a pearly white, translucent nodule with surface telangiectasias. As BCC is locally invasive, it can grow and lead to the formation of an ulcer. The characteristic edges of this ulcer are described as rolled out and beaded.
  • • Pearly white, translucent nodule with surface telangiectasias
  • • Ulcer with rolled out and beaded edges
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Sloping: Sloping edges are typically seen in healing ulcers.
  • • Option B. Sloping:
  • • Option C. Punched out: Punched out edges are characteristic of trophic ulcers.
  • • Option C. Punched out:
  • • Option D. Undermined: Undermined edges are seen in tubercular ulcers and chancroid.
  • • Option D. Undermined:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The edges of a basal cell carcinoma ulcer are characteristically described as rolled out and beaded, distinguishing it from other types of ulcers which have sloping, punched out, or undermined edges. ​

questions.text: A 35-year-old female took aspirin for headache and she developed wheezing and breathlessness. This will be associated with? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Nasal Polyp

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognizing the link between aspirin ingestion and respiratory symptoms in patients with nasal polyps is crucial for managing their condition effectively. Patients diagnosed with AERD should avoid NSAIDs and may need specific treatments for asthma and nasal polyps, along with alternatives to NSAIDs for pain management.
  • ➤ Samter’s triad: Asthma, Nasal polyposis (ethmoidal), Aspirin hypersensitivity

questions.text: A female patient presents to you with a unilateral headache. It is associated with nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia. What is the best drug for acute management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Sumatriptan

questions.text: A G2 with a previous LSCS underwent cesarean delivery. During surgery, there was excessive bleeding, and a hysterectomy had to be done. The image of the uterus is shown. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Placenta accrete syndrome involves abnormal placental adherence to the uterine wall, often leading to severe bleeding during delivery and requiring obstetric hysterectomy.

questions.text: Arrange the following in the sequence of auditory pathway: ( INICET Nov 2020) Cochlear nucleus Spiral ganglion Superior olivary nucleus Inferior colliculus Medial geniculate body
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 2 - 1 - 3 - 4 - 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence of structures involved in the auditory pathway from the periphery to the center is (E COLI MA). Eighth (Vestibulocochlear) nerve Cochlear Nucleus Superior Olivary nucleus Lateral lemniscus Inferior colliculus Medial geniculate body Auditory cortex The spiral ganglion situated in Rosenthal's canal contains bipolar cells. The dendrites of these bipolar cells join to form the cochlear branch of the vestibulocochlear nerve which ends in the cochlear nuclei.
  • ➤ The correct sequence of structures involved in the auditory pathway from the periphery to the center is (E COLI MA). Eighth (Vestibulocochlear) nerve Cochlear Nucleus Superior Olivary nucleus Lateral lemniscus Inferior colliculus Medial geniculate body Auditory cortex
  • ➤ Eighth (Vestibulocochlear) nerve Cochlear Nucleus Superior Olivary nucleus Lateral lemniscus Inferior colliculus Medial geniculate body Auditory cortex
  • ➤ Eighth (Vestibulocochlear) nerve
  • ➤ Cochlear Nucleus
  • ➤ Superior Olivary nucleus
  • ➤ Lateral lemniscus
  • ➤ Inferior colliculus
  • ➤ Medial geniculate body
  • ➤ Auditory cortex
  • ➤ The spiral ganglion situated in Rosenthal's canal contains bipolar cells. The dendrites of these bipolar cells join to form the cochlear branch of the vestibulocochlear nerve which ends in the cochlear nuclei.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy from Kerala presents with fever, headache, and drowsiness. His family reports that he has consumed palm fruit recently. Which virus is considered in the differential diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Nipah

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The presentation of fever, headache, and drowsiness in a boy from Kerala who has recently consumed palm fruit, a known vector for bat-related transmissions, suggests Nipah virus infection. Nipah virus is known for causing severe encephalitis and has been associated with outbreaks in Kerala, often linked to bat consumption of fruits and subsequent transmission to humans.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A. Dengue : Does not typically cause encephalitis, although severe dengue can lead to altered sensorium.
  • • Option A. Dengue
  • • Option C. Ebola : Not endemic in India and typically presents with hemorrhagic symptoms.
  • • Option C. Ebola
  • • Option D. Chikungunya : Causes fever and arthritis, not encephalitis.
  • • Option D. Chikungunya

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives:
  • ➤ Nipah virus should be considered in cases of encephalitis, especially in regions like Kerala, where outbreaks linked to bat consumption of palm fruit have been reported.

questions.text: A patient presents with a foreign body (chuna) in his eyes and complains of irritability and lacrimation. What is the first step of management in this patient? (INICET MAY 2024)

options.label: C
options.text: Irrigation of eye with normal saline

questions.correct_answer: C. Irrigation of eye with normal saline

Ans. C) Irrigation of eye with normal saline

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The first step in the management of chemical injuries to the eye is immediate and copious irrigation with normal saline to wash out the chemical substance

  • ➤ e.g.

  • ➤ Myelodysplastic syndromes
  • ➤ Hypersplenism
  • ➤ Megaloblastic anemia
  • ➤ III. Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria
  • ➤ IV. Bone marrow infiltrations
  • ➤ e.g:

  • ➤ Hematologic malignancies (leukemias, lymphomas, myeloma)

questions.text: When does stranger anxiety appear in a child? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 6-7 months

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Stranger anxiety typically emerges by 6-7 months of age.

questions.text: Which of the following regulates the body temperature? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The regulation of body temperature is primarily controlled by the hypothalamus. Specifically, the anterior nucleus of the hypothalamus is responsible for cooling mechanisms, akin to standing in front of an air conditioner during hot weather. Conversely, the posterior nucleus of the hypothalamus manages warming mechanisms, similar to standing near an exhaust to receive warm air during cold weather.
  • • anterior nucleus
  • • cooling
  • • posterior nucleus
  • • warming
  • • This dual role in temperature regulation is unique to the hypothalamus.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Basal ganglia: The basal ganglia are involved in the coordination of movement and motor control, but they do not play a role in temperature regulation.
  • • Option B. Basal ganglia:
  • • Option C. Thalamus: The thalamus acts as a relay station for sensory and motor signals to the cerebral cortex, and does not regulate body temperature.
  • • Option C. Thalamus:
  • • Option D. Limbic system: The limbic system is involved in emotions, behavior, and long-term memory, but it does not have a role in the regulation of body temperature.
  • • Option D. Limbic system:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The hypothalamus, specifically its anterior and posterior nuclei, is responsible for regulating body temperature.

questions.text: Which of the following is not the correct statement about papillary thyroid cancer? (FMGE JULY 2023)

options.label: C
options.text: Tests reveals elevated serum calcitonin levels

options.label: D
options.text: Most patients have a good prognosis

questions.correct_answer: C. Tests reveals elevated serum calcitonin levels
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Tests reveals elevated serum calcitonin levels

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Papillary thyroid cancer is not associated with elevated serum calcitonin levels; this is a characteristic feature of medullary thyroid cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following signs is not typically seen in allergic rhinitis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Otto veraguth folds

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Otto Veraguth folds are not associated with allergic rhinitis but are more commonly seen in individuals with depression.

questions.text: Identify the type of cartilage shown in the image below:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Elastic cartilage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is a risk factor for progression to borderline ovarian tumor? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Nulliparity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nulliparity is recognized as a risk factor for borderline ovarian tumors, highlighting the influence of reproductive factors on ovarian health.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features can be encountered in Korsakoff psychosis? (INICET MAY 2024) Amnesia Confabulation Ophthalmoplegia Peripheral neuropathy
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Korsakoff psychosis is characterized by severe memory impairment (amnesia), confabulation, and peripheral neuropathy. It does not include ophthalmoplegia, which is a feature of the acute Wernicke's encephalopathy.
